values.description: I added the `hx_read_sensors()` to the C API and rearranged the MATLAB functions following the same ordered that appears on the C API.
values.title: Update the API overview doc page

summary.raw: I added the `hx_read_sensors()` to the C API and rearranged the MATLAB functions following the same ordered that appears on the C API.
summary.html: I added the hx_read_sensors() to the C API and rearranged the MATLAB functions following the same ordered that appears on the C API.

values.description:
* enable MATLAB building on Linux
 * find `mex` instead of just `mex.bat`
 * customize `mex` args for Linux vs. Windows
 * put Octave and MATLAB .mex files into separate directories (both build and install)
 * add custom `mexopts.sh` file to allow customization of compiler flags

This works for me on Trusty, at least as far as running `hx_matlab_controller.m`.

I haven't tried it on Windows, but I don't think that I've broken that support (except maybe for the change of .mex install location; I'm not sure how the SDK gets produced).

Note: I first was getting this error:

~~~~
>> hx_read_sensors
Invalid MEX-file '/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/matlab/hxgz.mexa64':
/usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/bin/glnxa64/../../sys/os/glnxa64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.19' not found (required by
/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libhaptix-comm.so.0)

Error in hx_read_sensors (line 27)
  sensor = hxgz('read_sensors');
~~~~

The issue seems to be caused by the copy of `libstdc++.so` that ships with MATLAB.  After finding it recommended for working around similar problems with other tools (e.g., openoffice), I did the following:

~~~~
cd /usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/sys/os/glnxa64
sudo mv libstdc++.so.6 libstdc++.so.6.orig
~~~~

Effectively, that hides MATLAB's own c++ lib, which makes it use the system-installed one, which doesn't have the dependency problem.

This issue might be related to the fact that I'm building with gcc-4.8 (default on Trusty), and MATLAB only officially supports up through gcc-4.7 (you get a warning while building). Then again, I installed gcc-4.7 and built the .mex with it, and still got the same result.
values.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

summary.raw:
* enable MATLAB building on Linux
 * find `mex` instead of just `mex.bat`
 * customize `mex` args for Linux vs. Windows
 * put Octave and MATLAB .mex files into separate directories (both build and install)
 * add custom `mexopts.sh` file to allow customization of compiler flags

This works for me on Trusty, at least as far as running `hx_matlab_controller.m`.

I haven't tried it on Windows, but I don't think that I've broken that support (except maybe for the change of .mex install location; I'm not sure how the SDK gets produced).

Note: I first was getting this error:

~~~~
>> hx_read_sensors
Invalid MEX-file '/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/matlab/hxgz.mexa64':
/usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/bin/glnxa64/../../sys/os/glnxa64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.19' not found (required by
/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libhaptix-comm.so.0)

Error in hx_read_sensors (line 27)
  sensor = hxgz('read_sensors');
~~~~

The issue seems to be caused by the copy of `libstdc++.so` that ships with MATLAB.  After finding it recommended for working around similar problems with other tools (e.g., openoffice), I did the following:

~~~~
cd /usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/sys/os/glnxa64
sudo mv libstdc++.so.6 libstdc++.so.6.orig
~~~~

Effectively, that hides MATLAB's own c++ lib, which makes it use the system-installed one, which doesn't have the dependency problem.

This issue might be related to the fact that I'm building with gcc-4.8 (default on Trusty), and MATLAB only officially supports up through gcc-4.7 (you get a warning while building). Then again, I installed gcc-4.7 and built the .mex with it, and still got the same result.
summary.html:
• enable MATLAB building on Linux
  • find mex instead of just mex.bat
  • customize mex args for Linux vs. Windows
  • put Octave and MATLAB .mex files into separate directories (both build and install)
  • add custom mexopts.sh file to allow customization of compiler flags

This works for me on Trusty, at least as far as running hx_matlab_controller.m.

I haven't tried it on Windows, but I don't think that I've broken that support (except maybe for the change of .mex install location; I'm not sure how the SDK gets produced).

Note: I first was getting this error:

>> hx_read_sensors
Invalid MEX-file '/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/matlab/hxgz.mexa64':
/usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/bin/glnxa64/../../sys/os/glnxa64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.19' not found (required by
/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libhaptix-comm.so.0)

Error in hx_read_sensors (line 27)
  sensor = hxgz('read_sensors');

The issue seems to be caused by the copy of libstdc++.so that ships with MATLAB. After finding it recommended for working around similar problems with other tools (e.g., openoffice), I did the following:

cd /usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/sys/os/glnxa64
sudo mv libstdc++.so.6 libstdc++.so.6.orig

Effectively, that hides MATLAB's own c++ lib, which makes it use the system-installed one, which doesn't have the dependency problem.

This issue might be related to the fact that I'm building with gcc-4.8 (default on Trusty), and MATLAB only officially supports up through gcc-4.7 (you get a warning while building). Then again, I installed gcc-4.7 and built the .mex with it, and still got the same result.

values.description: With this change, both MATLAB and Octave will allow you to call `hx_connect()` with any number of arguments, including 0.  Previously, Octave would allow that, but MATLAB complained if you gave > 0 arguments.
values.title: Accept any arguments to hx_connect (#7)

summary.raw: With this change, both MATLAB and Octave will allow you to call `hx_connect()` with any number of arguments, including 0.  Previously, Octave would allow that, but MATLAB complained if you gave > 0 arguments.
summary.html: With this change, both MATLAB and Octave will allow you to call hx_connect() with any number of arguments, including 0. Previously, Octave would allow that, but MATLAB complained if you gave > 0 arguments.

values.description:
Turns out that MATLAB [wants](http://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/matlab_prog/capture-information-about-errors.html#bq9tdlq-1) the error message identifiers to follow a `component:mnemonic` syntax, and it complains if they don't (Octave doesn't care).

So here I'm adding a prefix `HAPTIX:` to each identifier.  Which this change, both MATLAB (at least on Linux) and Octave are happy.
values.title: Fix error-reporting in MATLAB (#8)

summary.raw:
Turns out that MATLAB [wants](http://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/matlab_prog/capture-information-about-errors.html#bq9tdlq-1) the error message identifiers to follow a `component:mnemonic` syntax, and it complains if they don't (Octave doesn't care).

So here I'm adding a prefix `HAPTIX:` to each identifier.  Which this change, both MATLAB (at least on Linux) and Octave are happy.
summary.html:
Turns out that MATLAB wants the error message identifiers to follow a component:mnemonic syntax, and it complains if they don't (Octave doesn't care).

So here I'm adding a prefix HAPTIX: to each identifier. Which this change, both MATLAB (at least on Linux) and Octave are happy.

values.description:
I tested this with both MATLAB (on Linux) and Octave.

To try it, you can add this line:

    cmd.ref_pos = cmd.ref_pos';

in `hx_matlab_controller.m`, after the loop where the `cmd.ref_pos` vector is filled in.  Then, without this patch, you should see just some wrist motion (because the mex is only looking at the first element of the column vector); with the patch, you should see the correct full-DOF motion.
values.title: Transpose incoming vectors if needed (#9)

summary.raw:
I tested this with both MATLAB (on Linux) and Octave.

To try it, you can add this line:

in `hx_matlab_controller.m`, after the loop where the `cmd.ref_pos` vector is filled in.  Then, without this patch, you should see just some wrist motion (because the mex is only looking at the first element of the column vector); with the patch, you should see the correct full-DOF motion.
summary.html:
I tested this with both MATLAB (on Linux) and Octave.

To try it, you can add this line:

cmd.ref_pos = cmd.ref_pos';

in hx_matlab_controller.m, after the loop where the cmd.ref_pos vector is filled in. Then, without this patch, you should see just some wrist motion (because the mex is only looking at the first element of the column vector); with the patch, you should see the correct full-DOF motion.

values.description: This change allows you to use the .mex file in MATLAB on Windows by browsing to the install tree (e.g., `haptix-comm/build/install/Release/lib/haptix-comm/mex`), without having to do any PATH setup.
values.title: Copy ZMQ .dll files into mex directory

summary.raw: This change allows you to use the .mex file in MATLAB on Windows by browsing to the install tree (e.g., `haptix-comm/build/install/Release/lib/haptix-comm/mex`), without having to do any PATH setup.
summary.html: This change allows you to use the .mex file in MATLAB on Windows by browsing to the install tree (e.g., haptix-comm/build/install/Release/lib/haptix-comm/mex), without having to do any PATH setup.

values.description:
* Protobuf messages to match the new C structs.
* haptix_sim_utils.h: Helper file that has a bunch of functions from converting between protobuf and structs.
* haptix_sim.cc: For each function defined in the API, we convert the struct to a protobuf, make the request using ign-transport and (if needed) create a struct with the response.
* haptix_sim_TEST.cc: Unit test.
values.title: Haptix_sim implementation

summary.raw:
* Protobuf messages to match the new C structs.
* haptix_sim_utils.h: Helper file that has a bunch of functions from converting between protobuf and structs.
* haptix_sim.cc: For each function defined in the API, we convert the struct to a protobuf, make the request using ign-transport and (if needed) create a struct with the response.
* haptix_sim_TEST.cc: Unit test.
summary.html:
• Protobuf messages to match the new C structs.
  • haptix_sim_utils.h: Helper file that has a bunch of functions from converting between protobuf and structs.
  • haptix_sim.cc: For each function defined in the API, we convert the struct to a protobuf, make the request using ign-transport and (if needed) create a struct with the response.
  • haptix_sim_TEST.cc: Unit test.

values.description:
When using a 64bits Windows (I'm taking this as a default option) MATLAB 32 bits is installed under `Program Files (x86)` while MATLAB 64 bits is installed under `Program Files`.

This PRs implements the selection of the proper path depending on the bitness requested to build.

32bits Windows installations should be handled manually, comments in the script are self explanatory.
values.title: Support for 32 bit matlab

summary.raw:
When using a 64bits Windows (I'm taking this as a default option) MATLAB 32 bits is installed under `Program Files (x86)` while MATLAB 64 bits is installed under `Program Files`.

This PRs implements the selection of the proper path depending on the bitness requested to build.

32bits Windows installations should be handled manually, comments in the script are self explanatory.
summary.html:
When using a 64bits Windows (I'm taking this as a default option) MATLAB 32 bits is installed under Program Files (x86) while MATLAB 64 bits is installed under Program Files.

This PRs implements the selection of the proper path depending on the bitness requested to build.

32bits Windows installations should be handled manually, comments in the script are self explanatory.

values.description: MATLAB hand movement was much slower than the Octave hand movement. The problem was caused by the `pause()` function in MATLAB. The accuracy of this function is really bad. I changed the `hx_matlab_controller.m` example to send commands at 50 Hz and include a busy wait to replace `pause()`. Now, the example has the same behavior in octave and MATLAB.
values.title: Fix minor problems in the examples

summary.raw: MATLAB hand movement was much slower than the Octave hand movement. The problem was caused by the `pause()` function in MATLAB. The accuracy of this function is really bad. I changed the `hx_matlab_controller.m` example to send commands at 50 Hz and include a busy wait to replace `pause()`. Now, the example has the same behavior in octave and MATLAB.
summary.html: MATLAB hand movement was much slower than the Octave hand movement. The problem was caused by the pause() function in MATLAB. The accuracy of this function is really bad. I changed the hx_matlab_controller.m example to send commands at 50 Hz and include a busy wait to replace pause(). Now, the example has the same behavior in octave and MATLAB.

values.title: Create a VERSION file on Windows

values.title: Added check for pdfTeX when searching for mex program

values.description:
Add mex (MATLAB / Octave) wrappers for the C functions in the new sim API.  Notes:

* ~~At the time of writing, for clarity this PR is targeted at the `sim_api` branch, upon which it relies.  Once `sim_api` is merged, this PR should be retargeted at `default`.~~
* ~~A major missing piece of this PR is documentation in each `.m` file that explains parameters and return values for each function.~~
* ~~Also missing is an example of how to use the functions.~~
* `hxs_example.m` demonstrates most API calls.
* ~~Currently missing is a test of this code (it will go into handsim).~~
* There's a [handsim PR](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/112) that uses `hxs_example.m` as a test.

Following @jacquelinekay 's example, here's a breakdown of review responsibility (for each, please check the implementation in `hxgz.c` and the function definition and documentation in the corresponding `hxs_*.m` file):

* @caguero: `hxs_add_model, hxs_remove_model, hxs_is_logging, hxs_start_logging, hxs_stop_logging, hxs_set_model_color, hxs_model_color`
* @scpeters: `hxs_model_collide_mode, hxs_set_model_collide_mode, hxs_contacts, hxs_set_model_joint_state, hxs_set_model_link_state`
* @hsu: `hxs_model_transform, hxs_set_model_transform, hxs_angular_velocity, hxs_set_angular_velocity, hxs_linear_velocity, hxs_set_linear_velocity, hxs_sim_info`
* @jacquelinekay: `hxs_reset, hxs_apply_force, hxs_apply_wrench, hxs_apply_torque,  hxs_camera_transform, hxs_set_camera_transform, hxs_model_gravity_mode, hxs_set_model_gravity_mode, hxs_example`

---

To test this code in Octave on Linux:

* `sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev` (to get the `mkoctfile` compiler)
* configure, make, and install
* `gazebo worlds/arat.world`
* `cd <prefix>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave`
* `octave`

Now, at the Octave prompt, you can try any of the `hxs_*.m` functions, without the `.m` suffix.  E.g., try `hxs_sim_info`.  To run the example: `hxs_example`.
values.title: Add mex wrappers for sim API

summary.raw:
Add mex (MATLAB / Octave) wrappers for the C functions in the new sim API.  Notes:

* ~~At the time of writing, for clarity this PR is targeted at the `sim_api` branch, upon which it relies.  Once `sim_api` is merged, this PR should be retargeted at `default`.~~
* ~~A major missing piece of this PR is documentation in each `.m` file that explains parameters and return values for each function.~~
* ~~Also missing is an example of how to use the functions.~~
* `hxs_example.m` demonstrates most API calls.
* ~~Currently missing is a test of this code (it will go into handsim).~~
* There's a [handsim PR](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/112) that uses `hxs_example.m` as a test.

Following @jacquelinekay 's example, here's a breakdown of review responsibility (for each, please check the implementation in `hxgz.c` and the function definition and documentation in the corresponding `hxs_*.m` file):

* @caguero: `hxs_add_model, hxs_remove_model, hxs_is_logging, hxs_start_logging, hxs_stop_logging, hxs_set_model_color, hxs_model_color`
* @scpeters: `hxs_model_collide_mode, hxs_set_model_collide_mode, hxs_contacts, hxs_set_model_joint_state, hxs_set_model_link_state`
* @hsu: `hxs_model_transform, hxs_set_model_transform, hxs_angular_velocity, hxs_set_angular_velocity, hxs_linear_velocity, hxs_set_linear_velocity, hxs_sim_info`
* @jacquelinekay: `hxs_reset, hxs_apply_force, hxs_apply_wrench, hxs_apply_torque,  hxs_camera_transform, hxs_set_camera_transform, hxs_model_gravity_mode, hxs_set_model_gravity_mode, hxs_example`

---

To test this code in Octave on Linux:

* `sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev` (to get the `mkoctfile` compiler)
* configure, make, and install
* `gazebo worlds/arat.world`
* `cd <prefix>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave`
* `octave`

Now, at the Octave prompt, you can try any of the `hxs_*.m` functions, without the `.m` suffix.  E.g., try `hxs_sim_info`.  To run the example: `hxs_example`.
summary.html:
Add mex (MATLAB / Octave) wrappers for the C functions in the new sim API. Notes:

  • At the time of writing, for clarity this PR is targeted at the sim_api branch, upon which it relies. Once sim_api is merged, this PR should be retargeted at default.
  • A major missing piece of this PR is documentation in each .m file that explains parameters and return values for each function.
  • Also missing is an example of how to use the functions.
  • hxs_example.m demonstrates most API calls.
  • Currently missing is a test of this code (it will go into handsim).
  • There's a handsim PR that uses hxs_example.m as a test.

Following @jacquelinekay 's example, here's a breakdown of review responsibility (for each, please check the implementation in hxgz.c and the function definition and documentation in the corresponding hxs_*.m file):

  • @caguero: hxs_add_model, hxs_remove_model, hxs_is_logging, hxs_start_logging, hxs_stop_logging, hxs_set_model_color, hxs_model_color
  • @scpeters: hxs_model_collide_mode, hxs_set_model_collide_mode, hxs_contacts, hxs_set_model_joint_state, hxs_set_model_link_state
  • @hsu: hxs_model_transform, hxs_set_model_transform, hxs_angular_velocity, hxs_set_angular_velocity, hxs_linear_velocity, hxs_set_linear_velocity, hxs_sim_info
  • @jacquelinekay: hxs_reset, hxs_apply_force, hxs_apply_wrench, hxs_apply_torque, hxs_camera_transform, hxs_set_camera_transform, hxs_model_gravity_mode, hxs_set_model_gravity_mode, hxs_example

To test this code in Octave on Linux:

  • sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev (to get the mkoctfile compiler)
  • configure, make, and install
  • gazebo worlds/arat.world
  • cd <prefix>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave
  • octave

Now, at the Octave prompt, you can try any of the hxs_*.m functions, without the .m suffix. E.g., try hxs_sim_info. To run the example: hxs_example.

values.description: While compiling haptix-comm on Windows I realized that `__func__` is not part of the standard and in Windows in called `__FUNCTION__`. This patch fixes the compilation problem on Windows.
values.title: Use __func__ on Windows.

summary.raw: While compiling haptix-comm on Windows I realized that `__func__` is not part of the standard and in Windows in called `__FUNCTION__`. This patch fixes the compilation problem on Windows.
summary.html: While compiling haptix-comm on Windows I realized that __func__ is not part of the standard and in Windows in called __FUNCTION__. This patch fixes the compilation problem on Windows.

values.description:
Two main issues:

* We were allocating an object of type hxsSimInfo on the stack. It turns out that hxsSimInfo is pretty big and we overflow the memory in the stack. Thanks to @gerkey for catching the problem.

* There's no way to use std::system on Windows to execute a non blocking command unless you use `start ` as a prefix. This will create a new `cmd` windows and run your command without blocking.

CI Results:

* [Here](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/7/) is our Jenkins job (pending).
values.title: Fix tests on Windows

summary.raw:
Two main issues:

* We were allocating an object of type hxsSimInfo on the stack. It turns out that hxsSimInfo is pretty big and we overflow the memory in the stack. Thanks to @gerkey for catching the problem.

* There's no way to use std::system on Windows to execute a non blocking command unless you use `start ` as a prefix. This will create a new `cmd` windows and run your command without blocking.

CI Results:

* [Here](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/7/) is our Jenkins job (pending).
summary.html:
Two main issues:

  • We were allocating an object of type hxsSimInfo on the stack. It turns out that hxsSimInfo is pretty big and we overflow the memory in the stack. Thanks to @gerkey for catching the problem.

  • There's no way to use std::system on Windows to execute a non blocking command unless you use start as a prefix. This will create a new cmd windows and run your command without blocking.

CI Results:

  • Here is our Jenkins job (pending).

values.description: After discussion with @hsu, I am removing `hxs_set_model_link_state` from the sim API because the underlying behavior in Gazebo for setting the position/velocity of an individual link in multi-link models is buggy and not something we want to expose to users until it gets patched.
values.title: removed hxs_set_model_link_state

summary.raw: After discussion with @hsu, I am removing `hxs_set_model_link_state` from the sim API because the underlying behavior in Gazebo for setting the position/velocity of an individual link in multi-link models is buggy and not something we want to expose to users until it gets patched.
summary.html: After discussion with @hsu, I am removing hxs_set_model_link_state from the sim API because the underlying behavior in Gazebo for setting the position/velocity of an individual link in multi-link models is buggy and not something we want to expose to users until it gets patched.

values.description: We included an `id` field in hxsModel but it's useless because the current API doesn't let you do anything with the `id`. We better remove it.
values.title: Remove id field from hxsModel

values.description:
I copied a helper function that we have in Ignition Transport to fork external processes and kill them. I also assigned a random partition to all the Ignition nodes running during testing.

[Jenkins is happy now](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/17/).
values.title: Fix Jenkins issues running tests on Windows

summary.raw:
I copied a helper function that we have in Ignition Transport to fork external processes and kill them. I also assigned a random partition to all the Ignition nodes running during testing.

[Jenkins is happy now](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/17/).
summary.html:
I copied a helper function that we have in Ignition Transport to fork external processes and kill them. I also assigned a random partition to all the Ignition nodes running during testing.

Jenkins is happy now.

values.description:
removed "id" key without updating `mxCreateCreateStructMatrix`:

~~~
octave:1> hxs_sim_info
[New Thread 0x7fffe34da700 (LWP 30135)]
[New Thread 0x7fffe2cd9700 (LWP 30136)]
[New Thread 0x7fffe24d8700 (LWP 30137)]
[New Thread 0x7fffe1cd7700 (LWP 30138)]
[New Thread 0x7fffe14d6700 (LWP 30139)]
[New Thread 0x7fffe0cd5700 (LWP 30140)]

Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
strlen () at ../sysdeps/x86_64/strlen.S:106
106	../sysdeps/x86_64/strlen.S: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt
#0  strlen () at ../sysdeps/x86_64/strlen.S:106
#1  0x00007ffff776c40b in mxArray::mxArray(int, int, int, char const**) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/liboctinterp.so.2
#2  0x00007ffff776c4c7 in mxCreateStructMatrix () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/liboctinterp.so.2

values.description:
All tests should be working on Linux and Windows.

CI tests:

* [Trusty is safe](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-trusty-amd64/13/)
* [Windows is safe](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/20/)
values.title: Test the simulation API using separate processes

summary.raw:
All tests should be working on Linux and Windows.

CI tests:

* [Trusty is safe](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-trusty-amd64/13/)
* [Windows is safe](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/20/)
summary.html:
All tests should be working on Linux and Windows.

CI tests:

  • Trusty is safe
  • Windows is safe

values.description:
This pull request updates `examples/hxs_requester.c` to be more illustrative of the sim API functionality. It is based on @gerkey's Matlab example, `matlab/hxs_example.m`, with a few omissions here and there.

I also add an example of using `hxs_contacts` in the Matlab example, and a line showing how to move the arm.

Testing `hxs_contacts` requires a change to the `hxsContactPoints` protobuf message, else octave will crash due to a protobuf exception when the example is run.

The Matlab example updates will be an integral part of the [upcoming sim API tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=haptix_sim_api&branch=haptix_sim_api).
values.title: Changed hxs_requester.c to match matlab example

summary.raw:
This pull request updates `examples/hxs_requester.c` to be more illustrative of the sim API functionality. It is based on @gerkey's Matlab example, `matlab/hxs_example.m`, with a few omissions here and there.

I also add an example of using `hxs_contacts` in the Matlab example, and a line showing how to move the arm.

Testing `hxs_contacts` requires a change to the `hxsContactPoints` protobuf message, else octave will crash due to a protobuf exception when the example is run.

The Matlab example updates will be an integral part of the [upcoming sim API tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=haptix_sim_api&branch=haptix_sim_api).
summary.html:
This pull request updates examples/hxs_requester.c to be more illustrative of the sim API functionality. It is based on @gerkey's Matlab example, matlab/hxs_example.m, with a few omissions here and there.

I also add an example of using hxs_contacts in the Matlab example, and a line showing how to move the arm.

Testing hxs_contacts requires a change to the hxsContactPoints protobuf message, else octave will crash due to a protobuf exception when the example is run.

The Matlab example updates will be an integral part of the upcoming sim API tutorial.

values.description:
Similar to [this ign-math pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-request/30), this pull request adds a script that builds haptix-comm docs and uploads them to the s3 bucket under the correct version folder.

If you're going to run the upload doc script from your machine, you need to configure S3 first. Instructions are on the internal wiki.

You can already view the uploaded docs for the latest version, 0.7.1, on the s3 bucket:

https://s3.amazonaws.com/osrf-distributions/haptix/api/0.7.1/haptix__sim_8h.html
values.title: Added cmake generation for upload doc script

summary.raw:
Similar to [this ign-math pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-request/30), this pull request adds a script that builds haptix-comm docs and uploads them to the s3 bucket under the correct version folder.

If you're going to run the upload doc script from your machine, you need to configure S3 first. Instructions are on the internal wiki.

You can already view the uploaded docs for the latest version, 0.7.1, on the s3 bucket:

https://s3.amazonaws.com/osrf-distributions/haptix/api/0.7.1/haptix__sim_8h.html
summary.html:
Similar to this ign-math pull request, this pull request adds a script that builds haptix-comm docs and uploads them to the s3 bucket under the correct version folder.

If you're going to run the upload doc script from your machine, you need to configure S3 first. Instructions are on the internal wiki.

You can already view the uploaded docs for the latest version, 0.7.1, on the s3 bucket:

https://s3.amazonaws.com/osrf-distributions/haptix/api/0.7.1/haptix__sim_8h.html

values.description:
`libhaptix-comm` is listed as a dependency in TestUtils.cmake, but it does not exist as a target, prompting the following cmake warning (cmake 3 on OS X)
~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at cmake/TestUtils.cmake:12 (add_dependencies):      
  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in         
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details. 
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning. 
                                                                         
  The dependency target "libhaptix-comm" of target "UNIT_haptix_TEST" does 
  not exist.                                                             
Call Stack (most recent call first):                                     
  src/CMakeLists.txt:16 (ign_build_tests)                                
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it. 
~~~

Also, the `protobuf_compilation` dependency target doesn't exist on OS X. Does it exist on other platforms?
~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at src/CMakeLists.txt:33 (add_dependencies):         
  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in         
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details. 
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning. 
                                                                         
  The dependency target "protobuf_compilation" of target "haptix-comm" does 
  not exist.                                                             
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.    
~~~

  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in         
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details. 
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning. 
                                                                         
  The dependency target "protobuf_compilation" of target "haptix-comm" does 
  not exist.                                                             
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.    
~~~
summary.html:
libhaptix-comm is listed as a dependency in TestUtils.cmake, but it does not exist as a target, prompting the following cmake warning (cmake 3 on OS X)

CMake Warning (dev) at cmake/TestUtils.cmake:12 (add_dependencies):      
  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in         
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details. 
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning. 

  The dependency target "libhaptix-comm" of target "UNIT_haptix_TEST" does 
  not exist.                                                             
Call Stack (most recent call first):                                     
  src/CMakeLists.txt:16 (ign_build_tests)                                
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.

Also, the protobuf_compilation dependency target doesn't exist on OS X. Does it exist on other platforms?

CMake Warning (dev) at src/CMakeLists.txt:33 (add_dependencies):         
  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in         
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details. 
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning. 

  The dependency target "protobuf_compilation" of target "haptix-comm" does 
  not exist.                                                             
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.

values.description:

values.description:
Needed for the [HAPTIX logging tutorial](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/280). ~~It requires [this](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-requests/148) handsim branch.~~

* `hxs_start_logging()` tweaked: The input parameter is now the directory where the log file is located.
* I added some commented blocks to the C++ and MATLAB examples that you can use for testing Gazebo logging.
values.title: Add logging to the C++ and MATLAB examples

summary.raw:
Needed for the [HAPTIX logging tutorial](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/280). ~~It requires [this](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-requests/148) handsim branch.~~

* `hxs_start_logging()` tweaked: The input parameter is now the directory where the log file is located.
* I added some commented blocks to the C++ and MATLAB examples that you can use for testing Gazebo logging.
summary.html:
Needed for the HAPTIX logging tutorial. It requires this handsim branch.

  • hxs_start_logging() tweaked: The input parameter is now the directory where the log file is located.
  • I added some commented blocks to the C++ and MATLAB examples that you can use for testing Gazebo logging.

values.description:
Latest changes in ignition-transport broke the MATLAB support in haptix-comm.

[Jenkins build with the haptix-comm generation fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-sdk_any-builder-windows7-amd64/35/)
values.title: Fix MATLAB support

summary.raw:
Latest changes in ignition-transport broke the MATLAB support in haptix-comm.

[Jenkins build with the haptix-comm generation fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-sdk_any-builder-windows7-amd64/35/)
summary.html:
Latest changes in ignition-transport broke the MATLAB support in haptix-comm.

Jenkins build with the haptix-comm generation fixed

values.description:
We have to update the examples because `ref_pos` is now before the gearbox.

Testing:

Run Gazebo:


```
#!c

gazebo worlds/arat.world
```

Run the C example:

```
#!c

<YOUR_HAPTIX-COMM_REPO>/example/build/controller
```

Run the octave example:


```
#!c

cd <HAPTIX_INSTALL_DIR>/lib/haptix-comm/octave
octave
hx_matlab_controller
```
values.title: Fix examples

summary.raw:
We have to update the examples because `ref_pos` is now before the gearbox.

Testing:

Run Gazebo:


```
#!c

gazebo worlds/arat.world
```

Run the C example:

```
#!c

<YOUR_HAPTIX-COMM_REPO>/example/build/controller
```

Run the octave example:

cd <HAPTIX_INSTALL_DIR>/lib/haptix-comm/octave
